GERMINATION

The growth of a viable seed into a photosynthesizing plant under favourable conditions such as suitable temperature, oxygen and water.

Most seeds need to take up water to germinate; this is known as imbibition. Imbibition is the taking up of liquid, causing swelling.  Water: hydrates enzymes in the seed, activating them. As a result, the seed begins to release energy from its food store for growth.

Epigeal germination 

A type of germination in which the cotyledons of the seed are raised above the soil level, e.g, broad bean seed and cow pea seed. 

Hypogeal germination 

A type of germination in which the cotyledons of the seed remain in the soil e.g. African yam bean seed and maize grain. 

 

UNN PUTME Example

1. Water is required for seed germination to take place because it____

A. activates the enzymes B. softens the testa

C. liberates energy for growth D. permits radicle growth E. allows oxygen to diffuse into the seed

(A. Most seeds need to take up water to germinate; this is known as imbibition. Imbibition the taking up of liquid, causing swelling.  Water: hydrates enzymes in the seed, activating them. As a result, the seed begins to release energy from its food store for growth, 2015/2016, no 3)
